quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 12 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 12.8: Le Chatelier's Principle: Temperature and Catalysts
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Thermal effects on equilibrium and the role of catalysts

questions.question: For an **exothermic** reaction ($A + B \rightleftharpoons C + heat$), increasing the temperature will:
options: Shift the equilibrium to the left and decrease the value of K
Shift the equilibrium to the right and increase the value of K
Shift the equilibrium to the left but keep K the same
Have no effect on the position of equilibrium
questions.explanation: In an exothermic reaction, heat is a product. Adding heat (increasing temperature) drives the reaction backward to consume the excess energy, which lowers the product-to-reactant ratio (K).

questions.question: In an **endothermic** reaction ($heat + A \rightleftharpoons B$), what happens when the temperature is increased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right and K increases
The equilibrium shifts to the left and K decreases
The equilibrium shifts to the right but K remains constant
The reaction stops because it runs out of energy
questions.explanation: Heat is a reactant in endothermic processes. Increasing temperature is like adding more reactant, which shifts the system to the right and increases the equilibrium constant.

questions.question: What is the effect of adding a **catalyst** to a system at equilibrium?
options: It has no effect on the equilibrium position or the value of K
It shifts the equilibrium toward the products
It increases the value of K by lowering the activation energy
It shifts the equilibrium toward the side with more moles of gas
questions.explanation: A catalyst speeds up the forward and reverse reactions equally. It helps a system *reach* equilibrium faster, but it does not change the concentrations once equilibrium is established.

questions.question: If cooling a reaction mixture causes it to turn from blue to pink, and pink is the product, the reaction must be:
options: Exothermic
Endothermic
Athermal (no heat change)
Catalyzed
questions.explanation: If removing heat (cooling) shifts the reaction toward the products, then heat must be a product. This defines an exothermic reaction.

questions.question: Which of the following is the **only** factor that can change the numerical value of the equilibrium constant K?
options: Temperature
Pressure
Concentration
Addition of a catalyst
questions.explanation: While other factors cause shifts in the *position* of equilibrium (changing Q), only temperature changes the actual ratio defined by K.

questions.question: For the Haber process ($N_{2} + 3H_{2} \rightleftharpoons 2NH_{3} + 92 kJ$), why is a moderate temperature used industrially instead of a very low one?
options: To ensure the reaction occurs at a practical speed
To increase the value of K to its maximum
To prevent the catalyst from melting
To shift the equilibrium toward the reactants
questions.explanation: Although low temperature favors the product (exothermic), it would make the reaction too slow to be useful. A compromise temperature provides a balance between yield and speed.

questions.question: Decreasing the temperature of an endothermic reaction will:
options: Decrease the value of K
Increase the value of K
Not change the value of K
Increase the rate of the forward reaction
questions.explanation: Removing heat from an endothermic reaction (where heat is a reactant) shifts the equilibrium to the left, resulting in a smaller K.

questions.question: A catalyst increases the rate of both forward and reverse reactions by:
options: Lowering the activation energy for both directions
Increasing the enthalpy of the reactants
Providing extra thermal energy to the molecules
Increasing the concentration of the activated complex
questions.explanation: By providing a different mechanism with a lower 'energy hill', it makes it easier for molecules to go both ways, without changing the net energy difference between start and finish.

questions.question: If a reaction is endothermic, a plot of $\ln K$ vs. $1/T$ (in Kelvin) will have a:
options: Negative slope
Positive slope
Zero slope (horizontal line)
Parabolic curve
questions.explanation: As $T$ increases, $1/T$ decreases. In an endothermic reaction, increasing $T$ increases $K$. This inverse relationship results in a negative slope ($-ΔH/R$) on a van't Hoff plot.

questions.question: In a reaction where $\Delta H = 0$ (no heat change), how does temperature affect the equilibrium position?
options: It has no effect on the equilibrium position or K
It favors the products
It favors the reactants
It makes the reaction irreversible
questions.explanation: If there is no heat absorbed or released, heat is neither a reactant nor a product. Therefore, Le Chatelier's Principle predicts no shift due to temperature changes.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've mastered the tricky relationship between heat and equilibrium.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You know how to treat heat as a chemical participant.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: Exothermic = heat is a product; Endothermic = heat is a reactant.
scoreMessages.0: Review how temperature changes the equilibrium constant K and the direction of shift.
